Graphical abstract Performing calcinations of the support in different atmospheres is a vital precondition for preparation of active cobalt supported on MgO–La2O3 catalyst for ammonia decomposition. This work studied the influence of support calcination conditions on basic properties, morphology and catalytic performance. The catalytic performance was evaluated in the temperature range of 300–550°C at atmospheric pressure. The XPS results showed the surface metal concentration was increased in 5wt% Co supported on MgLa mixed oxide catalyst (5CMLa–N2) whose support was calcined in N2 atmosphere. The TPR measurements showed strong metal support interaction in 5CMLa–N2 catalyst. From the SEM results the formation of MgLa mixed oxide was increased in 5CMLa–N2 catalyst. The moderate basic site density determined by CO2 TPD results was increased in 5CMLa–N2 catalysts compared with other catalysts. These outcomes are might be one of the reasons in enhancing activity in 5CMLa–N2 catalysts compared to other catalysts. Hence support calcinations under N2 being the best choice, was the one of the parameters that influenced on catalytic properties of the cobalt on MgO–La2O3 system, for ammonia decomposition. Keywords Ammonia decomposition Mg–La mixed oxides Cobalt catalyst Hydrogen production 1 Introduction Hydrogen is an alternative source for the generation of energy from fuel cell. This process is 100% green because it produces no pollutants. The main disadvantage of this process is delivery and storage of hydrogen. No H2-storage material till now satisfied the practical requirements of fuel cell application. Hence onsite generation of hydrogen is become an alternative. The choice of hydrogen production directly from carbonaceous substance like methanol and methane has its limitations, but the formation of CO x as a byproduct which degrades fuel cell performance [1]. Generation of CO x free hydrogen by ammonia decomposition (AD) is more attractive from practical and economical point of view compared to other process. Much research has been devoted to the investigation of Group VIII metals (Ru, Ni, Ir, Fe, Co and Rh) or metal carbide/nitrides (MoN x , VC x , MoC x , VN x , etc.) as catalytic materials for AD [2–5]. Previous studies showed that Ru supported on multi wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) is the most active catalyst for AD [4]. Unfortunately, MWCNTs as a support suffered from many drawbacks such as high cost, methanation of carbon at high temperatures and low metal support interaction. In addition the high price and limited availability of Ru which makes it unsuitable for large scale applications [6]. Therefore, developing a cheap and affordable active catalyst for AD is highly desirable. Transition metals such as Fe, Co and Ni are good candidate for this reaction. Unfortunately, the iron system is forming stable nitrides at low temperatures [7]. Although nickel is less expensive than cobalt, Ni catalysts are active at high temperatures [8–10]. It is also reported that support basicity plays a crucial role in AD thus the tailoring of the basic strength of mixed oxides supports with proper treatment could be used to design better catalysts for AD [1,5]. We reported MgLa supported cobalt system is efficient catalyst for ammonia decomposition. In comparison with other mixed oxides basic MgLa mixed oxide showed better activity. We also reported the optimized the Mg/La ratio (Mg/La=5) showed better activity compared with other Mg/La ratios [11]. But there is still scope to increase activity using MgLa supported Co system. To get a closer insight into the role of the support and aiming at better understanding of the supported cobalt system on AD the effect of calcination atmosphere of the support has been investigated. The effect of such treatment on support the variations in morphology and basicity is also been studied. To observe changes in activity clearly we selected MgLa mixed oxide support with MgLa ratio 3 (instead Mg/La=5). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Mg/La mixed oxide support (Mg/La=3) was prepared by co-precipitation from Mg and La nitrates solutions under high super saturation conditions using a mixture of KOH and K2CO3 [11]. The obtained precipitate is filtered, dried and divided into three equal portions. All portions were calcined at 450°C but in different atmospheres. The supports calcined in air, N2 and under vacuum were designated as MLa–Air, MLa–N2 and MLa–Vac, respectively. For comparison we prepared Mg/La mixed oxide with same Mg–La ratio using only KOH for precipitation followed by calcination in air at 450°C. This support was designated as MLa–OH. The prepared supports were impregnated with Co from aqueous cobalt nitrate solution using a rotary evaporator to obtain 5wt.% loading of Co. Impregnated precursors of all catalysts were dried in an oven overnight at 100°C followed by calcination at 500°C for 5h under nitrogen flow to obtain the final catalyst used for AD. Obtained catalysts were designated as 5CMLa–Air, 5CMLa–Vac, 5CMLa–N2 and 5CMLa–OH. 2.2 Catalyts characterization The BET surface area of the catalysts was determined by N2 physisorption at −196°C using a Quantachrome Nova2000 Win2 apparatus. Before measurements, the samples were degassed at 300°C for 3h. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed using a Quantachrome pulsar automated chemisorption analyser. Prior to testing, a 0.1g sample was loaded into reactor and pretreated with helium gas flow at 120°C for 60min to remove adsorbed water. After cooling down to 50°C, the helium flow was switched to 5% H2 in nitrogen at a flow rate of 15cm3 min−1. Then the reactor temperature was linearly increased from 50 to 800°C at a ramping rate of 5°Cmin−1. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to analyse effluent stream. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using an Inel Equinox 1000 powder diffractometer equipped with a CPS 180 detector (filtered Co Kα1 radiation, 40kV, 30mA, spinning sample holder). Powder pattern analyses were processed using Match© Crystal Impact software (v.1.11e) for phase identification (using both COD and PDF databases). All the data were collected under the same conditions. Infra red spectra were recorded in KBr matrix on Bruker Vertex 70/70v FT–IR spectrometer in the range of 500–4000cm−1. XPS measurements were carried out in a Specs GmbH high vacuum multi-technique surface analysis system equipped with an Mg–Kα 1253.6eV X-ray source. As a common practice in XPS studies, the adventitious hydrocarbon C1s line (284.8eV) corresponding to a CC bond was used as a binding energy reference for charge correction. Sample morphology was investigated by means of field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Quanta FEG450, FEI) using an ETD Everhart Thornley detector (HV mode) and a solid-state back scattering electron detector (VCD). Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 was employed to evaluate basic site distribution of the catalysts. Prior to the TPD experiment, the catalyst was pretreated by passing Helium gas at 450°C for 1h and then cooled to 60°C in He flow. CO2 gas is then adsorbed on pretreated catalyst at 60°C for 1h. After the completion of the adsorption the reactor temperature was brought up to 100°C and flushed with Helium for 1h to remove the physisorbed CO2. The temperature is then increased linearly at a ramping rate of 10°Cmin−1 from 100 to 800°C. At this temperature a 30min period of isothermal conditions were maintained, followed by cooling to room temperature. Desorption patterns were recorded using Quantachrome Pulsar automatic chemisorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements Catalytic activity measurements were performed in a PID system (Eng and Tech, Spain) with a fixed bed quartz reactor under atmospheric pressure. Before reaction tests, a 100mg catalyst sample was reduced by a mixture of nitrogen and hydrogen flow at 500°C for 5h. After activation, the catalysts were flushed with nitrogen at the same temperature and then the reactor was cooled to 300°C. A pure ammonia gas was introduced into the reactor at a GHSV of 6000h−1. The experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 300–550°C by a successive stepwise rise of 50°C. At each temperature, the reaction was performed until a steady state was achieved. Effluent gas analysis was performed by an online-connected gas chromatograph (GC-450 Varian, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Poropak Q column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical characterization The BET surface areas and pore volumes measured by nitrogen physisorption for calcined supports and reduced cobalt samples are summarized in Table 1 . The surface areas and measured pore volumes were in the range of 36–86m2g−1 and 0.035–0.096cm3g−1 respectively. The sequence of surface areas and pore volume of the supports is as follows MLa–OH>MLa–Vac>MLa–Air>MLa–N2. These differences in surface area of supports may be due to differences in formation Mg–La mixed oxide phase. The Mg–La mixed oxide generally has low surface area [12]. MLa–OH support showed the higher surface area than other supports. As a general tendency, impregnation of the support with cobalt resulted decrease in surface area as well as pore volume for all supports. This might be due to blockage of pores after metal impregnation. 3.2 X-ray diffraction analysis The XRD patterns of freshly calcined supports in different atmospheres are shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD results are clearly indicating (from Fig. 1) the presence of two types of lanthanum oxide carbonate phases along with MgO phase. According to literature [13] lanthanum oxide carbonate generally exists in three crystalline modifications (I, Ia and II). The three polymorph hold in arrangement of (La2O2)2+ layers separated by CO3 2− ions. Type I is tetragonal phase having square layers, while type Ia is described as monoclinic phase, distortion form of type I. Type II La2O2CO3 is completely indexed as the hexagonal unit cell. The support calcined under N2 atmosphere (MLa–N2, Fig. 1c) showed diffraction lines at 25.88°, 29.32°, 30.03°, 32.17°, 35.39°, 39.30°, 39.55°, 40.80°, 52.05°, 55.7°, 59.07°, 64.54° and 67.5° corresponds to La2O2CO3 phase [PDF: 00-037-0804, hexagonal, a =4.075Å and c =15.95Å]. On other hand, the support calcined under vacuum (MLa–Vac, Fig. 1b) showed diffraction lines at 26.66°,34.46°,36.31° and 52.29° corresponds to the La2CO5 phase [PDF: 00-023-0320, tetragonal, a =4.063Å, c =13.5Å]. In addition MLa–Vac support showed lanthanum oxide phase [PDF: 00-083-1344, hexagonal, a =3.93Å and c =6.13Å] whose diffraction lines were overlapped with lanthanum oxide carbonate diffraction lines. The support calcined in air atmosphere (MLa–Air) clearly showed both phases of lanthanum oxide carbonate but the hexagonal phase signals are more intense than that of tetragonal phase. Conversely the support MLa–OH showed more intense signals of tetragonal phase compare with the other phase. From these results it could be conclude that there are two type lanthanum species are present in these supports. One is tetragonal La2CO5 phase having cell parameters a =4.06Å c =3.5Å and the other one is hexagonal La2O2(CO3) phase having cell parameters a =4.075Å and c =15.95Å. This might be due the presence of bulk and mixed oxide form of lanthanum which is forming carbonates by exposing to air. Since lanthanum oxide is active against water, the preparation of metal supported solids would involve strong chemical and structural rearrangements in the support [14]. The X-ray results of the calcined cobalt catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . After metal impregnation all calcined cobalt catalysts are showed only hexagonal La2O2CO3 phase except 5CMLa–OH catalyst which still showing two phases of lanthanum oxide carbonate. This might be due to the interaction among the catalyst components and changes in the texture and material morphology during preparation (CoO/MgO–La2O3). No diffraction lines were observed for cobalt which may be due to small crystal size. The XRD patterns of reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . After reduction step all catalysts are showed La(OH)3 phase [PDF: 00-036-1481, hexagonal, a =6.528Å and c =3.85Å] along with La2O3 [PDF: 01-083-1344, hexagonal a =3.93Å and c =6.13Å] and MgO phase [PDF: 01-089-4248 cubic a =4.2Å]. After reduction the catalysts were exposed to air hence Lanthanum hydroxide will form by taking moisture from air. The diffraction peaks corresponding to La(OH)3 phase and La2O3 phase are much sharper in cases of 5CMLa–N2 catalyst compare to that of the other catalysts. This indicates increased in particle size which may be due to increased interaction between metal and support after reduction step. As result decreased in surface area will observe in this catalyst. These results are in good correlation with BET results in Table 1 where we observed the surface area of reduced 5CMLa–N2 is low compared to other catalysts. 5CMLa–OH catalyst showed majorly La2O2CO3 phase [PDF: 00-037-0804, hexagonal a =4.07Å and c =15.95Å] and MgO phase. This result clearly indicates the only major change observed after reduction step in case of 5CMLa–OH catalyst is phase transformation of tetragonal lanthanum oxide carbonate to hexagonal. 3.3 FT–IR analysis According literature [15,16] the FTIR spectra of MgLa mixed oxide with sharp band at 3700cm−1 and a broad band at 643cm−1 are corresponds to the stretching and bending vibrations for free OH group. The broad band at 3400–3435cm−1 corresponds to the bound OH group. The bands at 1462, 1086, and at 855cm−1 corresponds to the vibration of CO3 2− groups in hydrated lanthanum carbonate. The bands at 1508, 1465, 1087 and 856cm−1 corresponds to the vibration of CO3 2− groups in II-La2O2CO3. Similarly the bands at 1504, 1470, 1367, 1093 and 863cm−1 are corresponds to CO3 2 vibrations in Ia-La2O2CO3 or type I-La2O2CO3. The FTIR spectra of calcined MLa-X (X =Air,N2, Vac and OH) mixed oxides are presented in Fig. 4 . The FTIR spectra of MLa–N2 (Fig. 4b) showed bands at 3440, 1500, 1465, 1384, 1087 and 858cm−1. These bands are mainly corresponds to the vibrations of CO3 2− group in II-La2O2CO3. The broad band at 3440cm−1 indicates lanthanum carbonate might be in hydrated form, which was formed by reacting with moisture when exposed air. In addition the band at 1384cm−1 along with other bands is point out the presence of monoclinic or tetragonal La2O2CO3 in small quantity along with hexagonal lanthanum oxide carbonate. The FTIR spectra of MLa–Vac (Fig. 4c) showed bands at 3700, 1506, 1462, 1366, 1087 and 856cm−1. These bands are mainly corresponds to the vibrations of CO3 2− group in tetragonal La2O2CO3. The sharp peak at 3700cm−1 corresponds to vibration of OH group in lanthanum carbonate hydroxide or lanthanum hydroxide. These are formed due to reaction between La2O3, moister and CO2 when expose to air. The FTIR spectra of MLa–Air and MLa–OH supports are showing similar bands as that of MLa–N2 support. From Fig. 4 it is obvious that the shoulder in range 1360–1380cm−1is increased in the supports as following order MLa–N2 <MLa–Vac<MLa–OH<MLa–Air. This result indicates increasing tetragonal phase of La2O2CO3 in supports. The XRD pattern of MLa–Vac (in Fig. 1) showed only tetragonal La2O2CO3 but the IR results indicating the presence hexagonal La2O2CO3. According Le Van et al. [15] La2O3 react with CO2 in air gives amorphous carbonate. Hence the presence of amorphous lanthanum oxide carbonate because of the reaction of hexagonal La2O3 with CO2 in air. The FT-IR spectra of reduced catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5 . All reduced catalysts showed (in Fig. 5) presence of La(OH)3 and very low amount of carbonate species (inferred on the basis of peak intensities) except in case of 5CMLa–OH catalysts. This catalyst is still showing carbonate vibrations even after reduction step. All other catalysts are showed lanthanum hydroxide phase. 3.4 Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) Reducibility of calcined cobalt catalysts was studied by Temperature-programmed reduction technique and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Reduction peaks in Fig. 6 divided into three regions. One at relatively low temperature from 200–400°C, second one at 400–650°C and third one at high temperature region after 700°C. The two peaks in low temperature region could be assigned to the reduction of Co3O4–CoO and CoO– metallic cobalt respectively [17,18]. A very broad peak tailing up to 650°C in second region suggesting reduction of CoO having strong interaction with support. The third high temperature peak above 700°C is due to reduction of lanthanum carbonate [11,19]. Two major changes were observed in TPR pattern of 5CMLa–Vac and 5CMLa–N2 catalysts in low temperature region. One is no two stage reduction peak was observed and the other is Temperature maximum slightly shifted towards high temperature. The main reason for these changes is increase in metal support interaction which causes metal oxide reduction at high temperatures. Hence the low temperature peaks in TPR profiles of 5CMLa–Air and 5CMLa–OH characterizes the reduction of an oxidic cobalt surface phase, which is not stabilized by the interaction with support. On other side the low temperature reduction peak in 5CML–Vac and 5CML–N2 catalyst corresponds to strongly interacted cobalt oxide species. According to Zhang et al. [2] the easily reducible metal oxide can always easily aggregate into big particles during the calcination or reduction procedures. The only difference in these catalysts preparation (except 5CMLa–OH) was calcination atmosphere of the support. Hence MgLa support calcined in N2 and Vaccum atmospheres may enhance interaction between metal components in the support. Consequently H2-TPR curves of Co/MgLa catalysts are found to be a function of support pretreatment in different atmospheres. 3.5 Surface properties of cobalt catalysts XPS was used to determine the chemical and electronic nature of the catalyst surfaces. Fig. 7 displays the O1s spectra for the calcined supports and calcined supported cobalt catalysts. The peaks (in Fig. 7.1) in O1s spectra referred to the lattice oxygen ions (O2−) at 529.1±0.2eV and adsorbed oxygen species (O−/O2−) at 531.3±0.2eV for supports. Similarly the peaks (in Fig. 7.2) in O1s spectra referred to the lattice oxygen ions (O2−) at 529.5±0.2eV and adsorbed oxygen species (O−/O2−) at 531.6±0.2eV for catalysts [16]. The positions of O1s are shifted to higher binding energies for catalysts in comparison with binding energies of support. This indicates the electron density on oxygen species in catalysts surfaces are decreased after metal impregnation. The amount of lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen species are almost equal in case of supports (from Fig. 7.1). After metal impregnation the amount of lattice oxygen species is decreased in comparison with adsorbed oxygen species (from Fig. 7.2). This observation indicates rearrangement of support especially oxygen of lanthanum during metal impregnation or metal coverage on surface of catalyst due to interaction with lattice oxygen. It can be seen from Fig. 7.2 the 5CMLa–N2 catalyst has more lattice oxygen than other catalysts. Thus these results are suggesting support calcination in different atmospheres has an influence on the electronic properties. La 3d spectra of all supports and catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8 . The main La 3d5/2 peaks of all spectra are observed at BE values below 835.0eV. The amount of surface La is high in case of MLa–N2 support compare with that of other supports (from Table 2 ). Similarly the 5CMLa–N2 catalyst is showed higher amount of surface La than that of other catalysts (from Table 2). The MLa–Vac support showed lowest lanthanum quantity on surface compared with other supports, But after metal impregnation the calcined 5CMLa-Vac catalyst showed equal amount of surface La as that of 5CMLa–N2 catalyst. This indicates the rearrangement of La during metal impregnation. These results are correlating with XRD results where we observed tetragonal lanthanum carbonate phase in MLa–Vac support. After metal impregnation the calcined 5CMLa–Vac catalyst showed hexagonal lanthanum oxide carbonate. The binding energy value at 529.0eV can be assaigned to the lattice oxygen within La2O3 [16]. The amount of lattice oxygen and surface La are high in case of 5CMLa–N2 catalyst. This indicates presence of more LaO x species on surface of 5CMLa–N2 catalyst compare with other catalyst. According literature [11,16] the MgLa mixed oxide supported catalyst have LaO x species which is electron rich in nature and tends to donate electrons to neighboring oxygen. Jun Ni et al., [16] reported that the metal atoms are close in contact with La2O3 on the surface of MgLa mixed oxide supported Ni catalyst. A similar phenomenon is expecting in these catalysts. Thus these results are suggesting thermal treating of support in different atmospheres has an influence on the electronic properties of catalyst. XPS spectra of Co 2p region of all catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . The peak at BE 780.0eV is the characteristic of CoO with strong shake-up satellite peak at 5eV higher than its main peak and has spin-orbit coupling around 15.5eV. The spectra of all catalysts (from Fig. 9) contained a shake-up satellite signal, which indicates the presence of Co2+ species. The Co 2p3/2 binding energy of CoO in 5CMLa–N2 and 5CMLa–Vac catalysts is slightly higher than other catalysts which may indicate a stronger interaction between Co and the support for these catalysts. The quantification results of surface cobalt concentration were shown in Table 2. The order of surface cobalt concentration (atom %) for four catalysts is 5CMLa–N2 >5CMLa–Vac>5CMLa–Air>5CMLa–OH as shown in Table 2. When metal support interaction is weak, Co3O4 is a predominant surface phase. It can be seen from Fig. 9 that CoO is the major surface phase in calcined cobalt catalysts. According to literature [20] it is known that the interaction between the catalyst and its support affect the surface properties and thus overall catalytic activity. Interestingly the same order follows catalytic activity where higher surface concentration of Co results in higher activity. 3.6 CO2-TPD The basicity studies were performed on Mg–La support thermally treated in different atmospheres. The amount of desorbed carbon dioxide and the temperature of CO2 desorption are the criteria for estimation of the surface concentration and for the strength of the basic sites, respectively. CO2 TPD studies of cobalt catalyst supported on Mg–La mixed oxides are not shown because of very low intensities of the desorption peaks. The TPD profiles of Mg–La mixed oxides thermally treated in different atmospheres are displayed in Fig. 10 . According to literature CO2 TPD pattern of Mg–La mixed oxide shows three types (weak, moderate and strong) of basic sites [11,21]. A peak with T max varying within 100–200°C is attributed to interaction of CO2 with weak basic sites present in catalyst. A peak that appears at T max 300–500°C is due to interaction of CO2 with moderate basic sites of Mg–La catalyst and a desorption peak at 600–800°C is due to the interaction of CO2 with strong basic sites. It is clearly seen from Fig. 10 that all Mg-La mixed oxide supports showed moderate and strong basic sites. The moderate and strong basic sites are corresponds to presence of MgO and La2O2CO3 respectively. Thermal treatment of MgLa hydrotalcites in different atmospheres results changes in basic sites. MLa–Air support majorly showed strong basic sites and very low moderate basic sites. MLa–Vac showed increased amount of moderate basic sites and the T max is shifted to higher side simultaneously decrease in high temperature basic sites was observed (inferred on the basis of signal intensity). On other hand Mg–La hydrotalcite calcined under N2 atmosphere showed two peaks in moderate basicity region. The reason for these changes is might be due to increased interaction between MgO and La2O3. These results are clearly suggesting about increased interaction between components in MgLa mixed oxide incase of MLa–N2 & MLa–Vac in comparison with MLa–Air support. Hence thermal treatment of MgLa HT in different atmosphere leads to an increase in moderate basic sites. 3.7 SEM & TEM studies Sample morphologies were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The representative SEM images of MLa-X (X =Air, N2, Vac) supports are shown in Fig. 11 . The figure clearly shows that all supports are consisted mainly rice grain shape crystals along with flake or sponge morphology. The EDAX results are confirmed the flake or sponge morphology is corresponds to MgO and rice grain shape morphology is corresponds to MgLa mixed oxide. Thermal treating of MgLa support in different atmosphere leads to change in amount of mixed oxide phase. The MLa–N2 support showed mixed oxide as major proportion in comparison with other supports. The SEM and EDAX results showed that Air and Vaccum calcined MgLa supports are giving big bulk form of MgO and La2O3. The results are displayed in Fig. 12 . These results are correlated with BET result where MLa–N2 support showed lower surface area than other supports due to presence of higher mixed oxide. The microscopy image of rice grain shaped MgLa mixed oxide in MLa–N2 support is displayed Fig. 13 . The corresponding EDAX pattern and TEM image (inset) were also displayed. The image clearly showed that the mixed oxide having rice grain morphology is combination of several smaller mixed oxide components. The average size of each smaller mixed oxide is about 30–60nm. The EDAX results of a selected area (in Fig. 13) indicate the presence of Mg and La at an Mg-to-La ratio of 3.74. This confirms the presence of MgLa mixed oxide with near ratio of 3:1. Hence the support calcined under different atmospheres not only affects the interaction among the catalyst components, but also affect the morphology. The HRTEM image of reduced 5CMLa–N2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 14 . The metallic cobalt majorly observed in vicinity of MgO than on La2O3. This indicates stronger interaction between cobalt and MgO than with La2O3. Similar type of results was reported in literature using Ni on MgLa system [16]. The average cobalt particle size observed in 5CMLa–N2 is 2.5nm. The slightly increase in cobalt particle size was observed in other catalysts. The results are presented in Table 1. 3.8 Catalytic activity The results of catalytic activity measurements over Co catalysts supported on MgLa mixed oxide whose supports are calcined under different atmospheres are displayed in Fig. 15 . All results were obtained under steady state conditions. Because of endothermic character of ammonia decomposition reaction the activity increases with temperature. Among all prepared catalysts the 5CMLa–N2 catalyst showed highest activity. The sequential order of catalytic activity of all catalyst is as follows 5CMLa–N2 >5CMLa-Vac>5CMLa–Air>5CMLa–OH. The 5CMLa–N2 catalyst whose support was pretreated in nitrogen atmosphere demonstrates superior NH3 decomposition activity than other catalysts. The activity of 5CMLa–N2 sample was increased about 15% higher than 5CMLa–Air sample. The observed high catalytic activity of 5CMLa–N2 catalyst might be related to the following reasons: (i) Presence of high surface lattice oxygen and lanthanum compared to other catalysts. (ii) Presence of high surface cobalt concentration. (iii) Increase in moderate basic sites which are in reaction temperature range. (iv) Increased cobalt support interaction which could effectively transfer electron between metal and support. The activity measurements were performed at temperatures 300–500°C. According to Seetharamulu et al. [11] the moderate basic sites were responsible for ammonia decomposition. In this study we observed support basicity was changed by thermal treatment in different atmospheres. The MLa–N2 showed more number of moderate basic sites in comparison with other supports in this work. This indicates interactions were increased between MgO & La2O3 in MgLa mixed oxide with thermal treatment in N2 atmosphere. Thermal treatment of support in air is influenced on the availability of surface oxygen species in 5CMLa–Air catalyst (from Fig. 7). It was found in 5CMLa–Air catalyst that the nucleophilic lattice oxygen (O2−) decreased in comparison with surface electrophilic oxygen species (O2 −, O−). The availability of surface cobalt concentration was increased mainly in 5CMLa–N2 which contributed in conversion increment upto significant percentage. The results of activity at 550°C vs surface cobalt concentration in different catalysts are displayed in Fig. 16 . Thus the effect of support thermal treatment in different atmosphere played a significant role in catalytic activity. Arrhenius plots (lnĲk) vs. 1/T) for ammonia decomposition are presented in Fig. 17 and the obtained activation energies are shown in the inset. The only difference in preparation of these catalysts 5CMLa-X (X =N2, Vac, Air) is thermal treatment of support in different atmospheres. The 5CMLa–OH catalyst showed highest activation energy. The catalyst whose support thermally treated in N2 atmospheres (5CMLa–N2) showed lowest activation energy 67.1kJ/mol. This is value lower than reported activation of energy of 5% Co on MWCNTs system 76.3kJ/mol [18]. These results concluding support pretreatment in N2 atmosphere has great impact on the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions The influence of support calcination in different atmosphere on basic properties, morphology and catalytic performance plays a major role. Thermal treatment of support in N2 atmosphere was the best choice for good performance of the catalyst in ammonia decomposition. The enhanced catalytic activity stem from improved moderate basic sites which are due to increased interaction between Mg and La. The morphological changes also other responsible factor for higher activity. The higher activity of 5CMLa–N2 & 5CMLa–Vac was attributed to presence higher surface metal concentration, increase of surface La concentration. coredata.dc:description: Performing calcinations of the support in different atmospheres is a vital precondition for preparation of active cobalt supported on MgO–La2O3 catalyst for ammonia decomposition. This work studied the influence of support calcination conditions on basic properties, morphology and catalytic performance. The catalytic performance was evaluated in the temperature range of 300–550°C at atmospheric pressure. The XPS results showed the surface metal concentration was increased in 5wt% Co supported on MgLa mixed oxide catalyst (5CMLa–N2) whose support was calcined in N2 atmosphere. The TPR measurements showed strong metal support interaction in 5CMLa–N2 catalyst. From the SEM results the formation of MgLa mixed oxide was increased in 5CMLa–N2 catalyst. The moderate basic site density determined by CO2 TPD results was increased in 5CMLa–N2 catalysts compared with other catalysts. These outcomes are might be one of the reasons in enhancing activity in 5CMLa–N2 catalysts compared to other catalysts. Hence support calcinations under N2 being the best choice, was the one of the parameters that influenced on catalytic properties of the cobalt on MgO–La2O3 system, for ammonia decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen generation by ammonia decomposition using Co/MgO–La2O3 catalyst: Influence of support calcination atmosphere
